guys, I am somehow not able to find a solution to my (should be very trivial) problem, does someone have an idea how to do this? I need to add a gradient image as a background to my listview. The image should stretch across the whole listview and scroll with the content of it. So if I have lets say 100 cells and they go way out of the screen boundaries, the gradient image on the background should do so too. It was super easy to implement on iOS but I cannot seem to find a way on android. When I set it up as a background for the listview in xml, it only covers the visible screen area and therefore never scrolls with the content.

<@U0MBWFDT8> I am not the designer of this insanity.. I just, unfortunately, have to implement it :confused:
I do not believe that this is a designer’s idea.
Because they probably understand UX.

I really have no idea. Its another agency that delivers these designs to us and I have no word in anything really. The whole concept of the app is wrong, but that is another story :slightly_smiling_face:
Anyways, no ideas on how to implement the gradient guys?
If it’s a listview: no.

In the category bad ideas:
Use a framelayout to put a scrollview behind the listview. Put an imageview in the scrollview. Then calculate the total height of the listview in code and set the height to the imageview that's inside the scrollview. And connect the scrolling of the listview to the scrollview so that scrolls when you scroll the listview.
Or you calculate the gradient per item in the listview. So that every single item’s background flows into the next and you get the same effect.

yeah, that idea with scrollview behind listview came through my mind too, but I thought I am definitely overlooking something and there must be a way to set it up for the listview itself too. Ok, thanks a lot for your ideas, I will give it a try and see how it goes :slightly_smiling_face:

probably it would be a better idea to use a simple scrollview  (at a first glance it seems you have a limited set of items that should be included); this way you can simply set the gradient to a vertically oriented linear layout within the scrollview
creating any kind of adapter, for either ListView or RecyclerView doesn’t really makes sense when you have only a few static items, not to mention the overhead caused by multiple view types

does your recyclerview have an id
of course
It works inside Activity! But not inside fragment.
Even ordinary RecyclerView saves its scroll position in Activity! But not in a Fragment.
are you re-creating the fragment perhaps?

public final <T> T getSystemService(Class<T> serviceClass) {
        // Because subclasses may override getSystemService(String) we cannot
        // perform a lookup by class alone.  We must first map the class to its
        // service name then invoke the string-based method.
        String serviceName = getSystemServiceName(serviceClass);
